articles.headline: As Meatpacking Plants Reopen, Data About Worker Illness Remains Elusive
articles.snippet: Emails show local officials received conflicting signals from state leaders and meatpacking companies about how much information to release about outbreaks in plants.
articles.abstract: Emails show local officials received conflicting signals from state leaders and meatpacking companies about how much information to release about outbreaks in plants.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Smithfield Foods plant in Tar Heel, N.C., is one of the world’s largest pork processing facilities, employing about 4,500 people and slaughtering roughly 30,000 pigs a day at its peak.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery, David Yaffe-Bellany and Derek Kravitz

articles.headline: Remember the MOOCs? After Near-Death, They’re Booming
articles.snippet: The pioneering online learning networks offer hard-earned lessons for what works and what doesn’t with online education.
articles.abstract: The pioneering online learning networks offer hard-earned lessons for what works and what doesn’t with online education.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sandeep Gupta, a technology manager in California, sees the economic storm caused by the coronavirus as a time “to try to future-proof your working life.” So he is taking an online course in artificial intelligence.

articles.headline: The Price of a Virus Lockdown: Economic ‘Free Fall’ in California
articles.snippet: California’s strengths — as a hub for commerce, tourism and education in the Pacific Rim — have become liabilities in the pandemic.
articles.abstract: California’s strengths — as a hub for commerce, tourism and education in the Pacific Rim — have become liabilities in the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Locked down in their homes, the four former California governors clicked into a Zoom call and one after another described how they dealt with the crises that had defined their time in office. For Pete Wilson, it was the 1994 Northridge earthquake. Gray Davis evoked the electricity disaster that drove him out in a recall election, and Arnold Schwarzenegger and Jerry Brown lamented the Great Recession.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Campaigning in a Crisis: Obama, McCain and the 2008 Meltdown
articles.snippet: Barack Obama and John McCain were rocked by a national emergency during the 2008 campaign, and their responses decided the race, aides say. There are lessons for Joseph R. Biden Jr. and President Trump.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama and John McCain were rocked by a national emergency during the 2008 campaign, and their responses decided the race, aides say. There are lessons for Joseph R. Biden Jr. and President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a late Sunday afternoon in September 2008, and senior aides to Barack Obama were gathered at his presidential campaign headquarters in Chicago. Their latest polling showed that Mr. Obama, the Democratic nominee, had lost his lead over his opponent, Senator John McCain, since the Republican convention. They were worried.

articles.headline: China’s Young Struggle for Jobs in the Post-Outbreak Era
articles.snippet: Finding work for a generation has become a major priority for the country’s leaders, who have promised a better life in exchange for a lack of political freedom.
articles.abstract: Finding work for a generation has become a major priority for the country’s leaders, who have promised a better life in exchange for a lack of political freedom.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before China can fully recover from the devastation of the coronavirus outbreak, it needs to find people like Huang Bing a job.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: China’s Virus Apps May Outlast the Outbreak, Stirring Privacy Fears
articles.snippet: With the disease there mostly under control, officials are looking for new uses for the government software that’s now on many phones.
articles.abstract: With the disease there mostly under control, officials are looking for new uses for the government software that’s now on many phones.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the height of China’s coronavirus outbreak, officials made quick use of the fancy tracking devices in everybody’s pockets — their smartphones — to identify and isolate people who might be spreading the illness.

articles.headline: When the C.E.O., Already Facing a Crisis, Gets the Coronavirus
articles.snippet: Business cratered at Booking Holdings, the online travel giant. Then its chief executive found out he was sick, too.
articles.abstract: Business cratered at Booking Holdings, the online travel giant. Then its chief executive found out he was sick, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: Glenn Fogel was in crisis mode.

articles.headline: How the Taliban Outlasted a Superpower: Tenacity and Carnage
articles.snippet: The Taliban stand on the brink of realizing their most fervent desire: U.S. troops leaving Afghanistan. They have given up little of their extremist ideology to do it.
articles.abstract: The Taliban stand on the brink of realizing their most fervent desire: U.S. troops leaving Afghanistan. They have given up little of their extremist ideology to do it.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALINGAR, Afghanistan — Under the shade of a mulberry tree, near grave sites dotted with Taliban flags, a top insurgent military leader in eastern Afghanistan acknowledged that the group had suffered devastating losses from American strikes and government operations over the past decade.

articles.headline: Trump Pushes a Conspiracy Theory That Falsely Accuses a TV Host of Murder
articles.snippet: On Twitter and at a news conference, the president said Joe Scarborough was responsible for the death of Lori Klausutis, who worked for him when he was a congressman. But Twitter refused her husband’s request to have the false tweets removed.
articles.abstract: On Twitter and at a news conference, the president said Joe Scarborough was responsible for the death of Lori Klausutis, who worked for him when he was a congressman. But Twitter refused her husband’s request to have the false tweets removed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump smeared a prominent television host on Tuesday from the lectern in the Rose Garden with an unfounded allegation of murder, taking the politics of rage and conspiracy theory to a new level even as much of the political world barely took notice.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Astor
